content.description: A cyclone is a large-scale air mass that rotates around a strong center of low atmospheric pressure. In India, cyclones primarily affect coastal regions.
before: Keep emergency kit ready (water, food, medicines, torch, radio)
Charge all electronic devices and power banks
Secure loose objects outside your home
Know the location of nearest cyclone shelter
Keep important documents in waterproof container
Store 3 days worth of drinking water and non-perishable food
during: Do not venture outside even if weather seems calm (eye of storm)
If in a building, move to higher floors if flooding starts
Do not touch wet electrical equipment
Stay away from coastal areas and riverbanks
after: Wait for official 'all clear' before going outside
Avoid damaged areas and power lines
Check for injuries, provide first aid

content.description: Floods are the most common natural disaster in India, affecting millions annually. Proper preparation can save lives.
before: Identify evacuation routes and practice them
Learn how to turn off gas, electricity, and water
Store important documents in waterproof bags
during: Never walk or drive through flowing water (6 inches can knock you down)
If trapped, move to highest level and call for help
Stay away from electrical equipment if wet
Do not return home until authorities say it's safe
after: Avoid floodwater - it may be contaminated
Check for structural damage before entering buildings
Clean and disinfect everything that got wet
Throw away food that came in contact with floodwater
Use flashlights, not candles, for lighting

content.description: AQI is a measure of air quality that indicates how polluted the air is and what health effects might be a concern.

aqi_levels.health_impact: Minor breathing discomfort to sensitive people
Breathing discomfort to people with respiratory diseases
Breathing discomfort to most people on prolonged exposure
Affects healthy people and seriously impacts those with existing diseases

precautions: Check AQI daily before outdoor activities
Use N95 or N99 masks when AQI > 200
Keep windows closed when AQI is poor
Stay hydrated and eat antioxidant-rich foods

content.description: A heatwave is a period of abnormally high temperatures. It can lead to heat exhaustion, heat stroke, and even death if proper precautions are not taken.
warning_signs: Heat Cramps: Muscle pains/spasms in abdomen, arms or legs
Heat Exhaustion: Heavy sweating, weakness, nausea, headache
Heat Stroke: High body temperature (>40Â°C), confusion, loss of consciousness
prevention: Stay indoors during peak heat hours (11 AM - 3 PM)
Drink plenty of water (even if not thirsty)
Use umbrella, hat, or damp cloth on head when outside
Avoid tea, coffee, and carbonated drinks
Take cool showers multiple times a day
first_aid: Move person to cool place immediately
Give water/ORS if person is conscious
Call ambulance (108) if heat stroke suspected
DO NOT give aspirin or paracetamol

content.description: Earthquakes strike suddenly without warning. Knowing what to do can help protect you and your family.
before: Identify safe spots in each room (under sturdy table/desk)
Secure heavy furniture and appliances to walls
Keep emergency kit in accessible location
Plan and practice 'Drop, Cover, Hold' drill
Keep shoes and torch near bed
Know how to turn off gas, water, electricity
during: COVER head and neck under sturdy furniture
If indoors, stay indoors (don't run outside)
If outdoors, move away from buildings, trees, power lines
If in vehicle, stop safely and stay inside
after: Check for injuries, provide first aid
what_not_to_do: Don't light matches or candles (gas leak risk)
Don't stand in doorways (not safer than other locations)
